segments.text: Well, when I entered the Army, as I just mentioned, I think we probably had the initial edge, A&M officers did, over the West Point officers, military academy graduates, initially, in terms of branch knowledge.
And I think that's the only advantage we had, basically, over them, because their education
while it was branched in material, was still oriented very much toward the military profession, military history, customs of the service.
And of course, they were immaculate in formations.
And they excelled us in every way, I would say, in military precision formation.
Now, I think that when A&M went to the branch immaterial form of instruction, or body of instruction, then that advantage was lost.
I wouldn't think I could detect in the Vietnam era, for example, we were still getting the
We were getting the branching material officer then, but I don't think that advantage that we had in World War II time over the West Pointer existed anymore.
And that was only really in a matter of branch knowledge.
And knowledge, of course, is a very important element of leadership.
And so it gave the A&M officer a very good start.
It ends up the infantry or signal or whatever.
It was then up to him to keep the lead if he could.

I don't think that in wartime, World War II experience or Vietnam experience, I never really, or during my entire career, I was never conscious of the West Point versus other source officer controversy that you'd often seen discussed.
Now, in wartime, there's no question the Vietnam War was different, but in World War II, we needed every man that could bear arms.
We needed, with that tremendously rapid expansion of our armed forces, we needed everyone who could possibly command successfully at all levels.
And all of a sudden, this little army of 200,000, less than 200,000, became 14 million.
And we should never under-evaluate the importance of those professional officers in creating that huge army soundly and effectively.
Although those units were filled with people like me who came in from
reserve status, National Guard status, or commissioned in the course of the war status.
I never felt that I was at a disadvantage in competing for jobs or promotions in the Army with West Pointers.
If you can use that term, competing, I guess we're subconsciously or unconsciously competing.
Everybody's competing.
Yeah.
directly conscious of it.
So I think that much of that West Point controversy, which I used to hear a lot of in my younger, you know, my earlier years before World War II pretty much erased it.
I think that's a result more of a
earlier times.
Must have been.
I'm not familiar with those earlier details, but it's not significant now.
But I think it's a fair question to ask how we compare it, because A&M is producing officers to go into the Army and the other services, and it's fair to know how they stack up.
And certainly the professional military academies is a good point of comparison.
But you never felt that you were at a disadvantage in promotion throughout your entire career because you had not attended West Point?
Never did.
You know, there are two things about military service that particularly people who've been involved extensively in wars
in the Army at least, tend to settle on.
One is an outlook that fate is going to determine whether you live or die.
Most soldiers arrive at that after they've been in war sometime.
It may not be right, but they do.
What do you think?
And the other one is being at the right place at the right time makes an awful lot of difference in how you progress.
And that's true.
Of course, the fact is that if you're in the right place at the right time, you still have to produce to progress.
You say, how do I feel about faith?
What are your opinions on those two issues?
I agree with both of those.
I became a believer in faith.
I think it's as much, not that I was always in such frequent, or any soldier for that matter, so frequent and constant jeopardy, but I tell you, I was not an infantryman.
I have all the respect in the world for the infantry, and I was brought up in the Army, convinced, oriented to the fact that the battle is going to be won finally by the infantry.

Everybody else from the direct support field artillery where I was most of the time in World War II, all the way back to the guy shipping bullets, is working for the infantry in support of the infantry.
But those are the guys that, while battle is never constant, when they are in battle,
I can understand how they do become fatalists because it's one way to throw off the concern about it.
You're bound to be concerned about it, being under fire so frequently and so intensively as most of them are in an active battle.
Well, what about that idea of being at the right place at the right time?
Is that more important for a promotion in the military or is it more important that you do the job right?
In other words, do you determine your promotions, or just that fate, that ideal fate?
No, fate has something to do with that, too, I guess, the roll of the dice.
But it's not that simple.
You will be in the right place at the right time because somebody initially thought that's where you ought to be.
Whether it's a fellow reading your records
or whether it's the general up here who knows you and has served with you before, and he knows you, and he doesn't know the other candidates, so he wants you.
But however you got there, the fact that you have been in the right place at the right time to meet a test and did it, there's no question that
It has an influence on how you succeed, not only rank-wise, but in building your base of knowledge and experience and expertise.
I know I had a few classmates that I can recall, A&M classmates, that came out of World War II as captains.
I came out as a lieutenant colonel, and that wasn't unusual.
And some of those captains I knew pretty well from A&M days.
And they were victims of circumstance.
You know, being in the wrong place at the wrong time or not getting to the right place at the right time because they can't do it better than that.
You see some examples of that.
I always felt that where World War II and Vietnam experience, too, was concerned,
that I was in a position to be a profiteer of circumstance.

I couldn't have been in a better situation in wartime to have the opportunity to contribute and test yourself, be tested, and gain from success the satisfaction of knowing you're contributing something.
You're doing something right.
Good.
Effective.
So we're oversimplified by those two things, fate and being in the right place at the right time.
But there's something to it.
I think this believing in fate simply is a matter of covering the concerns.
Of possible death.
Of possible death.
And you get to where you think in terms of your friends that way, your comrades.
Any commander worth his salt is concerned about not overexposing his troops and not putting them in an unacceptable danger.
But he comes to think pretty much in terms of faith for them, too, I think.
I've seen...
As I said earlier, religion has been important to me, but I've seen deeply religious people that can put that more in terms of the Lord taking care of them more directly.
What is faith?
That's part of it.
Let's turn to your academic career.
Tell me about it.
When you went down there, did you have firm ideas?
Did you want to go into business, or did you have any idea?
Did you know what you wanted to do academically?
Yes, I wanted to be a banker for some reason.
I'm not sure what.
I wanted to get into banking.
So looking at A&M at that time, we didn't have a business major like we do now.
The nearest thing to it was agricultural administration with a major in marketing and finance.
And so that was my major.
I could never get the country out of me entirely.
My minor was animal husbandry.
In fact, I think my father always really expected me to come back here.
When you didn't, do you think that he was let down?
Beg your pardon?
When you did not return and stayed in the military, do you think he was let down?
I don't think so.
I think he might have been disappointed.
And I think the reason he thought I would come back was because
Of all the boys, I seemed to be the one that, I guess, showed perhaps more attachment to the land.
Maybe that was just a matter of demonstration rather than feeling.
And George, who it turned out was the one who did come back and stay, eventually come back, Dad thought would not want to be here, I think.
He never told me that.
But George, when he graduated from A&M, got into the production credit organization and did very well and had good jobs.
And eventually was sent back to Kauffman, took that office.
And then when Dad died suddenly, he came to, of course, take over the place, which was a natural thing to do.
Incidentally, I mentioned my dad dying by accidental death.
He had a 55 gallon oil drum rigged up to put air pressure on it and spray his cattle.
I just happened to be home en route to the ROTC camp when I was on the staff at A&M.

and went to town with him and he took that tank in and his pickup to get it aired up while I got a haircut and the boys at the station were busy and he aired that thing up himself and his uh obviously the lid had been weakened or something anyway the lid just blew off and that intake pipe struck him in the head and killed his uh
So, he lived a matter of a couple of hours, but never knew anything after that.
So, I just thought I'd explain that.
That must have had a big impact on you.
How old were you?
Twenty?
No, I was back from World War II then, and I was forty-eight.
I was not yet married, but I was, let's see, I would have been twenty-nine.
Well, you know, you can usually see a silver lining to every cloud.
The one we saw was that Dad would have been the world's worst invalid.
And so you can immediately appreciate that he was not just crippled.
And then if you accept that, you can appreciate that he didn't live into old age that incapacitated him.
Why do you say he'd be the world's worst cripple?
Because he was such an energetic, physical man.
Active man.
Active man.
At the age of 69, he never would admit that he'd lost any of his powers, you know, physical powers, or mental.
Now, at A&M, what classes, what type of coursework did you like?
Well, having chosen that course, majoring in marketing and finance, this, of course, starts basically with economics and then gets into, as the term describes.
So I guess I enjoyed all of those courses.
We had to have so much history and so much English.
And English never bothered me.
That was a great problem with a lot of my counterparts or comrades from small schools.
We were fortunate.
Had to have so much math.
Math was never my long suit.
But I liked the economics and the finance.
I kind of enjoyed accounting.
That was almost a minor by virtue of the course, you know.
Were there professors there that- But I particularly also, I never minded these required courses off-subject because they were all, I liked history, for example.
I wish I'd been a better student of it because it later became important to me.
Sure.
Were there professors there that were important to you or that you had a closer relationship with?
Not really, and I'll tell you why.
We all had our favorite professors, and we all had those that we liked.
Very few, I can't think of one that I really disliked.
But there was a distance between students and professors then.
As a matter of fact, you could still detect in the classrooms that the professors
still felt some responsibility for that matter discipline, which related to the military aspects of that university.
I'm sure that was a carryover from the early years.
Probably when they were very small, every professor had a role in the military training.
I don't know that to be a fact, but I often suspected that.
And I never had any special problems.
I did become quite close to...
You know, I'm embarrassed I can't call his name.
He was an animal husbandry professor, and he winds up getting me in trouble because he talked me into taking advanced statistics course.
Buenas tardes.
Come on.
Si, okay.
Yo no se donde esta.
We're talking about an academic career
at A&M.
Do you think that the career that you had, the academic career that you had, prepared you for banking?
Yeah, sure do.
I was really looking forward until it became obvious that we were going to the Army.
I was looking forward to getting to that bank and learning all about it.
Okay, now you told me that you had a job lined up.
Yes, sir.
Will you relate that?
I had a dean, Kyle, who was dean of the School of Agriculture, my dean,
really did this.
I applied properly and all that, but I think his influence got me a job with the Federal Land Bank in Houston.
And he took me down there to meet the top people, and the president told me that his plan was to move me from department to department.
And as I absorbed that, I'd make the full circle, and then they'd decide what to do with me.
But I thought that was a wonderful opportunity.
But of course, it was becoming more and more obvious, and we were ordered
to active duty upon graduation, knew it was going to happen before we ever graduated.
All these jobs, everybody, generally speaking, had a job lined up early in the second semester.
So, anyway, I thought my course was very appropriate for what I was setting out to do.
By May of 1941, then, you had prepared yourself to go into the military.
You bet.
I've got to tell you a little story that I think is very American and also is...
somewhat descriptive of the way we were thinking in that last semester of my senior year.

And every outfit, you know, these little military outfits that we live in, we all, members of our class, become very close and extremely close by the time you reach your senior year, because it's been a lost process.
Two fine fellows in C battery in my class were
adapted Americans.
Ty Kovach, Japanese, full-blooded Japanese.
He was born in this country.
His parents were not.
And Peter Kousoulis, Pedro Kousoulis, from Laredo, whose father was a Greek immigrant who married a Spanish lady, Mexican lady, at the border.
And Pete, boy, they're wonderful guys.
Pete talked with a Greek-Mexican accent, if you can imagine that.

At this time, of course, in our last semester, we were devoting most of our bullet session time to the possibilities of getting into this war, World War II, and to the events of the day that outrageous related to the war.

This particular night we were in my room and mine and Anderson's room and reviewing the news of the day and the German-American boon led by Fritz Kuhn, you were too young to attach to that I guess, but he had just displayed very arrogant and we thought misguided energies up in New York I believe it was to organize a Nazi...
support organization in the United States, and of course this just incensed us.

And I'll never forget, Peter Kasulis was ordinarily a very quiet fella, but when he got stirred up, he did get stirred up, and he listened and finally joined into this conversation about the German-American boon with one very brief but strong statement.
He beat the desk and he says, the trouble with this country, there's too many foreign pimples in it.
Which I think is a splendid testimony of the immigrant American.
He's just as American as anybody.
Of course, he was born in this country.
But that very near attachment to foreign land meant nothing to him.
He was just as involved as we were.
Sure.
How about your Japanese friend?
Oh, he was the same.
He was the same, and a fine man.
His father was a
His father was a truck farmer down near Houston, and Ty succeeded him in that and is still there.
Ty lost his wife recently.
I called him when I learned about it.
An interesting thing, I went to war against the Japanese.
There was a great deal of sentiment, as you know, about the Japanese problem in this country.
And Ty and I were very good friends, but he just would never initiate a communication to me.
And the only reason I could, when I was over there, and the only reason I could, I never asked him, was he didn't want to prejudice me in any way by putting that Ty Kovacs on his letter.
You know, everything going in and coming out.
That just may be a...
What happened to him during the war?
The reason to reinforce that thought, the week after the war was over, I got a letter from him.
He, in the late stages of the war, was drafted.
Not early.
He didn't have a commission.
Did he graduate?
He graduated.
Why didn't he have a commission?
He was not selected for the advanced course.
You see, in those days,
Everyone was in the cadet corps except graduate students and crippled.
And even though there were only a certain number of contracts that were made with the juniors to pursue advanced military science after their first two years.
And there were quite a number that weren't selected.
Incidentally, we got paid a little bit for that too, you know.
But if you weren't, you still stayed in your military outfit.
You still had your
Class privileges.
You still had your seniority within the organization.
And so after the first two years, he was not selected.
That's right.
But he was drafted during the Second World War?
Yes.
He was not given a commission?
No.
He was drafted.
I forget now just what the timing was, but it was late in the war.
I think in the early part of the war, I don't know that the Japanese presidents had anything to do with it.
I rather think that he was necessary to agriculture, you know,
Anybody producing like they produced were significant in the picture.
I mean, this is food for Houston industrial workers.
Did he go to the European theater?
I don'tI think he was sent to the Pacific after the war actually was over.
You know, after the surrender.
Sure.
Okay.
As I recall.
It's been so long I just don't piece it all together.
Now, a lot of people say that A&M is more than an institution of higher learning, but it's something special.
What are your thoughts on that?
Well, I agree with that, at least that I know it.
First of all, we got that sense of oneness
And the A&M spirit that stuck with us, and I think that's a plus.
But also, I think that Cadet Corps always thought so.
Whether you went in the military or not initially put you ahead of your contemporaries.
Whether you're going into an engineering job, now my class didn't get to do that.
I think the best example, of course, I can think of are those just ahead of me, the two or three classes ahead of me.
You always remember the classmen ahead of you better than the ones behind you because you were looking up to them.

And the reason it did was because that experience they got in that cadet corps put them ahead relatively in the same fashion I've described to you that put us ahead of the West Point graduate, except in the sense that
It was the leadership aspect more, in that case, than the knowledge aspect.

You were just bound, if you came out of A&M as having been a cadet officer, and having commanded a company or higher unit, you just had to have accumulated some leadership and management experiences in there.
I don't think they're separate terms.
I think leadership's enough.
That the guy in the ordinary,
education institution didn't get.
That's why I say yes.
What way do you think going to Ann now changed your life?
I'm not sure that I can say it changed my life.
I think it opened up my future to a much...
more advantageous future than I could have ever had otherwise.
So it gave you new advantages.
You bet.
New opportunities.
You bet.
But as far as changing my life, it didn't change any of my basics.
It didn't change...
I don't think it changed any of my standards.
But it gave me new opportunities.
Okay.
Let's move on to your military career, then.
Tell me how you received your commission, and let's start right in on your first duty station.
Before the first semester of my senior year, I was invited to apply for a regular Army commission.
You know, ordinarily we're commissioned as lieutenants of the reserve.
I got the actual forms when I was at home Christmas holidays to apply for a regular Army commission.
And I studied that, thought about it, and I went to my dad and I said, Dad, I don't want a military career.
I don't know why I should.
I've never given any consideration to a military career.
I said, I've enjoyed being in this cadet corps, but that's not my goal.
I said, I think I'll just send this back to them, to the Army.
This came out of Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio.
And, of course, fathers are supposed to give good advice to their youngsters.
And he said, well, I tell you, maybe that's the way that you shouldn't choose to accept that.
But you don't know what a military career would be like, and you don't know what
a banking career would be like.
But you could go down and talk to Colonel Beasley, and he could probably enlighten you on this.
Why don't you do that?

So I called Colonel Beasley, and during my holidays and his, I went down and told him what the situation was, and I said, now, I'd just like you to tell me what I should consider before I act on this.
Colonel Beasley was a very beloved instructor of field artillery.
He was our senior field artillery instructor.
And you asked if I'd been very close.
I guess I was as close to him in regard as any of them, and also, through those years, a professional as far as the Corps versus military staff was concerned.
He gave me a wonderful

critique of a military career I thought he didn't try to talk me into accepting that and he didn't agree with me that I should let it go but he says I may be wrong but he says I believe that we're going to get in this war and if we do you're going to find out what the military is like
And if you do, if you had this regular commission and you like what you found, then you're set.
But if we do go to this war and when it's over, you don't have regular commission but would like to have had it, you'll regret having sent this back.
So I decided to take it, and I got it.
I decided to apply, and I was given it.

So I was commissioned a second lieutenant in the reserves for just a matter of weeks until the West Point class graduated, and I was commissioned in the regular army, second lieutenant field artillery, with standing just behind the class of West Point.
In other words, I was
Even though he graduated earlier, they did that on purpose?
Oh, yes.
That'd be fair.
Those guys had given four years of complete time to preparing for commissioning.
So we were commissioned behind them.
Now, there were five others in A&M who got regular commissions.
Only five others?
Yeah.
All the rest got reserved?
There were a total of six, two of whom were commissioned in the Marines and four in the Army.
Mm-hmm.
Of those commissioned in the Marines, both made it a career.
Of those commissioned in the Army, three of us made it a career.
My first assignment was to the 1st Cavalry Division at Fort Bliss, Texas.
Did any, just parenthetically, did any of those others who received regular commissions ever make it to general?
No, no.
They were fine officers, but
No.
So your first assignment was?
I was assigned to the And this is in June of 1941?
In June of 1941.
I was assigned to the artillery of the 1st Cavalry Division.
That division was still a horse cavalry division in 1941.
As I recall, we had around 8,000 horses.
The artillery was horse two.
The battalion in the artillery that I joined initially was mounted.
It was a motorized artillery unit, but it left shortly thereafter, and I was reassigned.
to the 61st Field Artillery Battalion, which was a horse unit.
And four and a half years later, I was given command of that division in the Philippines, of that battalion, 61st Field Artillery Battalion.
So I stayed with it the whole war.
You're talking about being in the right place at the right time.
When vacancies occurred, I was there.
and I consider myself most fortunate to have been there and to have succeeded to the command of the battalion.
But anyway, we thought we were going to fight the war on the Mexican border because who's going to send the horse outfit to fight these days?
But in the summer of 43, two years later, pretty late, actually in the
winter of 43.
We had our horses taken away, and we were made just really, in the cavalry division form of organization, we were really made a light infantry division.
We never lost our name, but that's what we were.
Were you sorry to see the horses go?
Well, under the circumstances, emotionally we were.
But as a matter of reason, we were glad that they were gone because nobody wanted to tell his grandchild that he was on the Mexican borders securing El Paso all through World War II on a horse.
But I don't believe that I've ever witnessed a more emotional day in the Army, even considering some of the traumatic memorials to casualties.

as was shown, that's an extreme statement to make, but it's because when those horses were taken away, because there were this mass of old soldiers, the non-cons particularly, hundreds and hundreds of them, who'd been nothing but horse soldiers, and a horse becomes just like your friend, you know.
It just becomes like a family member.
And when they led those horses away, you never saw such emotion in your life.
Very interesting, I thought.
These old servants are crying?
You bet.
Oh, it was unbelievable.
But anyway, an era had ended, too.
Sure.
And we all were conscious of that.
But at the same time, we were glad that we were getting shaped up.
Actually, we'd been lined up to go to the Pacific when this occurred.
For those two years, then, what was your job at Fort Bliss?
And what was it, training, basically, or can you explain?
Well, that's the job of every division.
If it's not in combat, it's training.
And we had the best trained division, I think, that ever went overseas because, I say that because of the nature of that division.
Our personnel were kept intact more.
They trained more constantly.
We had less, we provided less cadremen to other new outfits than any division in the Army.
Mm-hmm.
And so we were just extremely well-trained and very realistic.
We had a commander, division commander, General I.P.
Swift.
He was a West Point graduate.
He was a splendid training commander.
He was a good leader.
And we couldn't have been in better conditions when we went overseas.
But anyway, I was initially what's called an assistant battery executive officer.
I did just about everything those first few months that a battery officer would do, except I'd take command.
And then I was given command of a battery.
I'd have to check my doggone record there, but a matter of months after I entered.
Yes.
What was the month?
It just says 1942.
Is that when you were promoted to first lieutenant?
No, that was after I was promoted to first lieutenant.
How about captain?
I was promptly promoted to captain.
Okay, so you were promoted to captain on the 2nd of November, 1942.
Well, I was given the battery before I was promoted.
And I went overseas with the division commanding that battery.
Then after we'd been overseas for a while and before, we went over in July of 1943,
Before we were actually committed to combat, we were in Australia.
Okay, well, let's get back to Texas.
All right.
What were the problems of training?
Well, there were no real problems, but it was real field soldiers.
See, we were right there in Fort Bliss on the edge of that vast desert.

and uh you go through training cycles if you've taken in a number of recruits then you get cycle back sort of the basic things until they kind of get to where they can work and then you cycle through small unit training and then battalion and regimental training and division things where everybody's out and then you go to uh
as we did both summers after I joined the division.
I missed one of them.
We went to Louisiana Maneuvers with other divisions and did mock warfare.
Excellent training.
So you were prepared.
You bet.
Now, were you eagerthis is July of 43.
We'd been in war for a year and a half.
You were still in America, had been training for all that time.
Were you eager to go to war?
You bet, and that's why we were the only reason we were glad to see those horses go because
Because we were so attached to them, you know.
But that meant you were going to war.
But that meant we were going to war.
And anybody in wartime that is an average American, he wants to be a part of it.
He wants to do his part of it.
Did you have a desire to go either to the Pacific or Europe on one way or the other?
It doesn't matter, really.
As it turned out, the

the Japanese war was a dirty war the war with the Japanese in many respects but I guess we all adjusted what we're committed to and I at least felt that we were in a preferred situation there to Europe why well in the first place we were less susceptible to the
Of course, it was a war of mobility in Europe, but to the line on line, you know.
We did a great deal of, I think John MacArthur did a beautiful job of executing a very imaginative strategy.
So we didn't get bogged down anywhere, and we kept leaping great distances, and we always were winning.
We didn't have any serious reversals.
Our casualties were many, of course.
By and large, they were in the infantry and the people directly supporting them.
So, in a sense, we didn't have to put up with the terrible artillery that the Germans could deliver on our troops or the dive bombers.

One time where we were really, in my division, exposed to serious air action by the enemy, and that was in Lady when we had only carrier support and that big naval battle occurred which crippled most of our carriers and therefore immobilized our support aircraft.
But I think more than those things, it's just that you know what you're doing.
You know what it's like where you are.
and therefore you prefer that to the unknown.
So I guess what I'm saying is that we had many disadvantages, but it didn't bother us.
Disadvantages are that, as I say, the Japanese were a very, very sticky, difficult, mean enemy because of his training and commitment to the fight to the death.
The tropics are just pretty dirty

place with mosquitoes and snakes and other insects and other reptiles and as I have expressed it for 18 months between Australia and Luzon in the Philippines for 18 months I never heard a door slam that means you're living on the ground or in best in tents and I think our
Our fellow soldiers in Europe were managing a little better than that some of the time.
On the other hand, another big factor, I'd much rather be in the heat of the tropics than in the severe cold of the winter in Europe.
That's my personal viewpoint.
Tell me about your movement in July of 43.
When you left Texas, where'd you go?
We left Texas, went to San Francisco, and embarked for Brisbane, Australia.
and we went across by individual transport ship and without incident.
Were you in convoys exactly?
No, there were no convoys.

The theory was, as passed on, was that those individual ships were faster than the convoy escorts, and therefore your chances of, and actually faster than submarines, and our Navy was trying to keep up with where the submarines are, but of course they couldn't bear it too well.
So there's a certain amount of luck in it, I guess.
But also one ship's harder to spot than a whole bunch.
And we arrived in Australia, of course, in July in Australia.
It was wintertime.
It was pretty cold when we got there.
And we were there five months.
Really?
Mainly.
Five months?
Five months.
And we got very impatient.
I bet.
And the reason was that...

As best we could figure out, and I guess I should have read the, I'm sure there's a detailed history written by the Army that someday when I'm not so busy I'm going to read, but it seemed that there just was not an advantageous place to commit us during those five months.
Also, we had a great opportunity to continue training and get people into our outfits to
that had actually been in combat up there in this different kind of fighting.
So that was very advantageous.
But I think the main reason was they just hadn't decided where to commit us.
We were a strategic reserve those first five months, which is a very logical thing, too.
Did you start jungle warfare tactic training then?
